articles.title: The Democrats’ New Litmus Test: Gun Control
articles.summary: Candidates for the 2018 House midterms are pushing a muscular firearms-regulation agenda, a wholesale repositioning on the issue in a party that avoided pushing new limits for a generation after the 1994 assault-weapons ban cost members their jobs in Congress.

articles.title: Elon Musk’s Flawed Plan for Tesla Shareholders
articles.summary: Elon Musk’s latest piece of showmanship—an offer to take electric-car maker Tesla private—amounts to a slap in the face for shareholders, writes James Mackintosh.

articles.title: Sumner Redstone Trust Restricts Sale Options for CBS, Viacom
articles.summary: Sumner Redstone doesn’t want his heirs to have an easy time selling off his family’s controlling stakes in media companies Viacom and CBS, according to his estate-planning documents.

articles.title: Tribune Terminates $3.9 Billion Merger With Rival Sinclair
articles.summary: Tribune Media terminated its merger agreement with rival TV station-owner Sinclair Broadcast Group and sued the company, alleging it failed to make sufficient efforts to get their $3.9 billion deal approved.

articles.title: Economists See Growth Hitting 3% in 2018
articles.summary: Economists are boosting their projections for growth in U.S. output this year, but trade disputes, a fading boost from fiscal stimulus and rising rates leave them thinking strong growth won’t last much longer than that.

articles.title: U.S. Sanctions Put Russia on Edge
articles.summary: Russian officials and companies were bracing for further economic pain, as the U.S. decision to punish the Kremlin for an alleged nerve-agent attack in the U.K. diminished hopes of a bilateral thaw.

articles.title: Valuations Are Slipping Even as Stocks Hover Near Records
articles.summary: Stock-market valuations are lower now than they have been for a while, but that doesn’t mean shares are cheap.

articles.title: For Uber and Airbnb, New York City Turns Foe
articles.summary: Two measures in New York City could hamper Silicon Valley heavyweights Uber Technologies and Airbnb as they prep for potential initial public offerings expected as soon as next year.

articles.title: Saudi Students Fret After Order to Leave Canada
articles.summary: Saudi Arabia’s escalating diplomatic row with Canada has upended the lives of thousands of Saudi students at Canadian universities who have been ordered out of the country by the kingdom.
articles.byline: Kim Mackrael and Paul Vieira in Ottawa and Donna Abdulaziz in Jeddah

articles.title: Meet the Chatbots Providing Mental Health Care
articles.summary: Researchers are working to teach empathy to artificially intelligent messaging tools, with the goal of supplementing human therapists.

articles.title: Bots vs. Trolls: How AI Could Clean Up Social Media
articles.summary: Many tools exist that could help identify bad actors on social media. There’s just no consensus on how to use them.

articles.title: Trump’s Tax Wisdom
articles.summary: The economics profession starts to give him his due.

articles.title: The ‘Red Wave’ Illusion
articles.summary: Evidence builds of major GOP losses in November.

articles.title: The ‘Blue Wave’ May Be Receding
articles.summary: Tuesday’s elections show that the GOP has a fighting chance to keep the House.

articles.title: I Won’t Ride the Trump Train Into a Trade War
articles.summary: Colleagues are appalled I support any of his policies. He may offset the good ones with reckless tariffs.

articles.title: How American Basketball Players Perfected the Eurostep
articles.summary: The Eurostep was exotic when it came to the NBA. Now it’s universal for today’s generation of youth basketball players.

articles.title: The Original Pop Parodist
articles.summary: Spike Jones, who entertained 1940s America with his subversively ironic musical slapstick, deserves to be better known today.

articles.title: The Best One-Liners in America Are on the Highway
articles.summary: To get their messages across, transportation officials engage in creative writing on electronic billboards; ‘Spend money on lobstahs, not speeding tickets’

articles.title: How Should Pepsi’s Indra Nooyi Be Graded?
articles.summary: The outgoing CEO’s final report card speaks to an important debate. What is more valuable: maximized shareholder returns or management stability?

articles.title: Fish Caught in America, Processed in China Get Trapped by Trade Dispute
articles.summary: The next round of U.S. tariffs aimed at Chinese imports could wind up hurting a major American product: fish.
articles.byline: Heather Haddon and Jesse Newman | Photographs by Simon Simard for The Wall Street Journal

articles.title: Trucking’s Tight Capacity Squeezes U.S. Businesses
articles.summary: Companies are pointing to rising freight costs as a drag on earnings and growth, as trucking companies raise rates at a historic pace and one says finding trucks is getting “ugly.”

articles.title: Third Point, Campbell Heir Push Soup Maker to Sell
articles.summary: Activist investor Third Point LLC is pushing for a sale of Campbell Soup Co. with the help of an heir to the soup company’s founder.

articles.title: WeWork Raises $1 Billion in Debt From SoftBank as Revenue Doubles
articles.summary: WeWork on Thursday disclosed it raised another $1 billion in funding from SoftBank, as the shared-office company continues its rapid growth by doubling revenue but piling up losses, according to newly released financial information on Thursday.

articles.title: Yelp Shares Surge on Ad Business Growth
articles.summary: Yelp’s shares gained about 29% in trading Thursday after the online review company had record growth in paying advertising accounts and stronger-than-expected ad revenue in its latest quarter.

articles.title: Clergy Balk as European Politicians Brandish the Crucifix
articles.summary: Across Europe, nationalists and upstart politicians are promoting the use of Christian imagery as they seek to change the Continent’s established politics and define Europe as Christian in reaction to Muslim immigration.
articles.byline: Francis X. Rocca and Drew Hinshaw

articles.title: Airstrikes Kill Dozens Including Children in Yemen
articles.summary: Airstrikes on a market in northern Yemen killed dozens of people, including children in a school bus, drawing international condemnation and putting a spotlight on a U.S.-backed Saudi military coalition.

articles.title: In Orban’s Hungary, a Glimpse of Europe’s Demise
articles.summary: Onetime dissident cozies up to Putin, betting that the post-Cold War era of liberal democracy is doomed. Among the economic and political implications: Hungary is building a giant Russian-designed nuclear power plant that will give Moscow leverage over its energy supply for decades to come.

articles.title: Argentina Rejects Bill to Ease Abortion Restrictions
articles.summary: Argentina’s Senate rejected a bill to legalize elective abortions, delivering a setback to activists in Latin America who hoped the vote would be a major step forward in loosening the region’s strict antiabortion laws.

articles.title: Discrepancy Over Saudi Oil Data Could Rattle Markets
articles.summary: Saudi Arabia has pressured independent energy analysts to alter their estimates of its oil production, which could put it in conflict with OPEC members.
articles.byline: Summer Said in Cairo and Benoit Faucon in London

articles.title: Dollar Pushes Ahead as Investors Seek Safety
articles.summary: The dollar’s persistent strength continues to reverberate around global markets, with a range of currencies taking a hit Thursday.

articles.title: Hedge Fund Backed by Industry Leaders Closes Its Doors
articles.summary: A hedge fund backed by some of the industry’s biggest names, Cerrano Capital, is closing less than a year after it got off the ground, the latest sign of the difficulties new funds are having raising money.

articles.title: JPMorgan’s ETF Business Is Finally Catching Up to Goldman
articles.summary: JPMorgan Chase’s exchange-traded funds raked in $2.5 billion in July, a record haul for the bank that signals a turnaround for the lagging four-year-old business.

articles.title: A Fight Over Voter Rights in California
articles.summary: A trial has put the liberal enclave of Santa Monica in effect on the same side as a conservative legal activist who is challenging the state’s voting-rights law.

articles.title: Pence Lays Out Plans for ‘Space Force’ Sought by Trump
articles.summary: Vice President Mike Pence laid out an ambitious plan to put President Trump’s stamp on the U.S. military by creating a command dedicated to space—the Space Force.

articles.title: Bank Worker Testifies Manafort Signed Loan Application With False Information
articles.summary: The government’s case against Paul Manafort, the former Trump campaign chairman, neared its end with testimony regarding a mortgage-loan application in which Mr. Manafort allegedly supplied false information.
articles.byline: Aruna Viswanatha and Del Quentin Wilber

articles.title: Hurricane Death Toll in Puerto Rico May Have Topped 1,400
articles.summary: The Puerto Rican government acknowledged in a document filed to Congress that the death toll from Hurricane Maria last year may have exceeded 1,400, though the official count stands at 64.

articles.title: Photos Capture Devastation From Carr Fire in California
articles.summary: Survey some of the damage from the Carr fire, the fifth most-destructive fire in California history, in aerial photos taken by the city of Redding.
articles.byline: Dave Cole | Photographs by the City of Redding

articles.title: Your A-to-Z Guide to Skin Care Today
articles.summary: A helpful rundown of the trendiest ingredients of the moment—from humble drugstore staples to extravagant masks made of 24-karat gold.

articles.title: The New Intimidation-Free Way to Get a Custom Suit
articles.summary: A new guard of millennial tailors is reinventing the fusty art of bespoke menswear, and removing the intimidation factor

articles.title: The Case for a Second Gym Membership
articles.summary: If your regular workout leaves you limp, go directly to one of these techy new fitness studios to...recover. Tom Brady does it—but is a bonus rehab gym worth another $1,800 or more a year?

articles.title: A Film Editor on How Movies and TV Shows Suck You Into a Scene
articles.summary: Joyce Arrastia, film editor of ‘Hotel Transylvania 3: Summer Vacation’ on her love of electric BMWs, making the first move on dating apps and the hypnotic powers of ‘The Crown.’

articles.title: Vegetarian Steak? This Recipe Proves It’s Not an Oxymoron
articles.summary: The secret ingredient is one we have plenty of at this time of year: zucchini. Cut it thick, char it on the grill and sink your teeth in.

articles.title: Cooking a Steak Just Got a Whole Lot Smarter
articles.summary: We pit digital meat thermometers against each other to test which ones are well done.

articles.title: How to Eat to Beat the Heat, Korean Style
articles.summary: Korea’s refreshing repertoire of chilled noodle dishes is everything you want right now. Think of them as edible air conditioning.

articles.title: Finally, Light Beers That Aren’t Light on Flavor
articles.summary: These aren’t the anemic brews of yesteryear. Now, craft breweries are dialing back the alcohol and the calories but keeping full-on taste.

articles.title: On Planes, Dogs Are Winning
articles.summary: New airline rules haven’t stopped an increase in pets, including emotional-support animals, on airplanes, leading to more incidents and questions about whether the government should step in.

articles.title: For Spike Lee, ‘BlacKkKlansman’ Is a Period Piece Best Viewed Now
articles.summary: The real-life tale of a black police officer’s infiltration of the Ku Klux Klan is set in the 1970s, but according to filmmaker Spike Lee, the racism it depicts persists today.

articles.title: Should You Decorate a Guest Room With Twin Beds?
articles.summary: Some designers insist that twin beds are more chic and practical. Advocates of queens and kings strongly disagree. We argue both sides.

articles.title: If the ‘Mona Lisa’ Were Made of Flowers...
articles.summary: To create an arrangement inspired by the renaissance canvas, floral designer Lindsey Taylor turns to her late-summer garden for hues as complex and varied as da Vinci’s immortal portrait.

articles.title: The Genetic Test Some Men Don’t Know They Need
articles.summary: Women are far more likely to get tested for inherited BRCA and other gene mutations, even though they also pose a cancer risk for men and their children.

articles.title: The Sum of This Ford’s Parts: A Very Strange Car
articles.summary: How a family modified a 1970 Cortina with water faucets, vanity mirrors and the floors of a defunct bowling alley.

articles.title: A Museum Show Where the Exhibits Are for Sale
articles.summary: In a new installation at New York’s Whitney Museum from the fashion brand Eckhaus Latta, visitors can buy the items on display, raising the question: Is it still an exhibition if you can shop it?

articles.title: ‘Crazy Rich Asians’ Seeks Mainstream Movie Success
articles.summary: “Crazy Rich Asians,” a breezy tale about an over-the-top wedding in Singapore, arose from Kevin Kwan’s frustration at the fresh-off-the-boat depictions of Asian-Americans in popular culture.

articles.title: Sotheby’s Sales Climb, Boosted by Private and Online Buyers
articles.summary: Sotheby’s sold $3.45 billion of art during the first half of 2018, a 22% increase from the year-earlier period and another sign of the art market’s health.

articles.title: Will the Smartphone Ever Truly Replace Your Beloved Wallet?
articles.summary: When “there’s an app” for everything, the contents of our wallets—cash, mementos, timeworn IDs—are giving way to slick digital replacements. Six writers consider why it’s bittersweet to say goodbye to the billfold.

articles.title: 2019 Mercedes-Benz CLS: A Move Toward Electrification
articles.summary: The third-generation CLS has the strong lines, powerful engine and luxury flair you’ve come to expect. But with its EQ Boost, Mercedes finally takes a small step toward electrification. Dan Neil reports

articles.title: The Cultish Home That Draws Fans of Americana Design
articles.summary: A design writer soaks in the décor of Beauport—the 46-room Massachusetts summer home of a pioneering decorator that’s become an insider destination.

articles.title: Leonardo in an Art Workshop: The Boy Most Likely to Succeed
articles.summary: A new exhibition at Yale shows the artist’s staggering gifts as he trained in the workshop of Andrea del Verrocchio in Florence.

articles.title: The Streaming Age Is Upon Us—and It’s Going to Get Ugly
articles.summary: Streaming was supposed to save us money, but Americans could end up paying more than their old cable bills to get all the new services coming online.

articles.title: Salman Rushdie’s New Novel Jumps Into Presidential Politics
articles.summary: In Salman Rushdie’s novel “The Golden House,” out Sept. 5, a tycoon from India reinvents himself in Manhattan as the Obama years end and the Trump administration begins.

articles.title: A Rapper Sends a Suicide Lifeline
articles.summary: The rapper Logic’s anthem titled ‘1-800-273-8255’ drives calls to a suicide hotline—while fueling the artist’s breakthrough on the hit-music charts.

articles.title: ‘Polina’ Review: Risky Leaps, Moving Odyssey
articles.summary: From a husband-and-wife team comes an emotionally compelling, brilliantly acted film about a Russian dancer.

articles.title: John le Carré Returns to George Smiley’s World
articles.summary: John le Carré brings back George Smiley in the Cold War novelist’s sequel to ‘The Spy Who Came In From the Cold.’

articles.title: You Don’t Know George Bernard Shaw Till You’ve Seen Him
articles.summary: Reading a play is one thing, but to truly understand the work requires a trip to the theater.

articles.title: A Surprise Dance Album
articles.summary: Joshua Homme opens up ‘the steam valve for joy’ on Queens of the Stone Age’s seventh album.

articles.title: Current Memoirs Hinge on Harrowing Pasts
articles.summary: A spate of memoirs by women detail various forms of abuse in their families and marriages.

articles.title: The Case for Kendrick Lamar
articles.summary: Five reasons the Compton rapper, with eight MTV Video Music Awards nominations, is heir to hip-hop’s greats.

articles.title: The Key to Avoiding Financial Surprises on the First Day of College
articles.summary: Families can take steps to be sure a student’s finances are in order before the school year starts.

articles.title: How Investors Can Cash In on the M&A Boom
articles.summary: Mutual funds and ETFs let individuals play the merger-arbitrage game once reserved for hedge funds and professional traders.

articles.title: Why Banks May Not Be the Best Place to Convert Currency
articles.summary: There are cheaper and more-transparent ways to safely send and receive money across borders.

articles.title: The Rise of the Fashionable Concrete Home
articles.summary: Long associated with utility, the material is now popular for constructing stylish luxury houses. Such homes are expensive to build but easy to maintain.

articles.title: Young Families Embrace Living in ‘Wuthering Heights Country’
articles.summary: Amid a slow housing market, cash-rich buyers prop up prices in the moors of northern England made famous by Emily Brontë novels.

articles.title: Inside an Oslo Home Immortalized by Edvard Munch
articles.summary: Located in Norway’s capital, the home later was occupied by a woman who fought the Nazis and then by a top actress. It is now listed for about $2.2 million.

articles.title: Vote for the WSJ House of the Week
articles.summary: Will it be a postbellum plantation in Georgia, a Manhattan bachelor pad made family-friendly or a Parisian gem with a garden?

articles.title: How Dionne Warwick Fought to Be Heard
articles.summary: The singer grew up in a musical family in New Jersey. When she warned two songwriters, ‘Don’t make me over,’ the line became her first hit.

articles.title: Diane Kruger and Norman Reedus Buy Manhattan Townhouse
articles.summary: The “In the Fade” and “Walking Dead” stars paid $11.75 million for a 19th-century West Village home.

articles.title: NBC’s McFadden Asks $6 Million for Manhattan Townhouse
articles.summary: The NBC News correspondent wants to trade her Upper East Side brownstone, which Oscar-winning filmmaker Elia Kazan once called home, for an apartment.

articles.title: Giant Colorado Ranch With Private Saloon Seeks $36 Million
articles.summary: Near the ski resorts of Steamboat and Breckenridge, the 6,000-plus acre property also has a chalet-base for sporting activities.

articles.title: A Parisian Gem With a Garden
articles.summary: An artsy couple spent almost two years looking for this apartment, which dates back to the 18th century, in the 7th arrondissement. It is asking about $14.7 million.

articles.title: A Postbellum Plantation in Georgia
articles.summary: The owners of this property in the Quail Belt wanted a Southern-style home with modern infrastructure and hunting options. It is asking $3.195 million.

articles.title: A New York Bachelor Pad Made Family Friendly
articles.summary: This prewar loft in Manhattan was originally built as an edgy home for a single man. It is asking $4.5 million.

articles.title: Freddie Mac Has a New Plan to Cap Rent Increases
articles.summary: Freddie Mac, the country’s largest backer of apartment loans, is rolling out a new program that will offer lower-cost financing to owners who agree to cap rent increases for the life of their loans.

articles.title: Oceanfront Maui Home, Lighthouse Included, Seeks a Sales Record
articles.summary: Located in a resort community, the 10-acre Hawaiian property is asking $49 million.

articles.title: Ultramodern California Home—and Popular TV Ad Spot—Asks $30 Million
articles.summary: La Jolla’s cliff-side ‘Razor House’ overlooks the Pacific Ocean and has a circular living room.

articles.title: De Beers Heiress Lists UFO-Style Home for a Record $11 Million
articles.summary: Located near Seattle, the space-style residence sits on 80 acres and was designed to be self-sustaining.

articles.title: Shopping for a Luxury Home? Now You Can Try Before You Buy
articles.summary: High-end developers of resort-residences are offering likely buyers brief—and sometimes free—mini-vacations in specially designed tents, cabins and cabanas.

articles.title: A Restored Château in the French Countryside
articles.summary: Located in the Dordogne region, this home, with a yoga studio, is on 182 acres with a lake. It is asking $4.06 million.

articles.title: On the Market: Katharine Graham’s Summer Estate for $39.5 Million
articles.summary: A trust linked to the family of the late Washington Post publisher is selling a large portion of her Martha’s Vineyard beachfront property.

articles.title: China’s Tariff Turnaround: U.S. Crude Oil Drops Off the Target List
articles.summary: As China made good on its threat to impose 25% tariffs on $16 billion worth of U.S. imports, one big-ticket item originally on its hit list was conspicuously missing: crude oil.

articles.title: Israel and Hamas Clash Again, Threatening Peace Talks
articles.summary: Israel’s military said militants from Gaza fired at least 180 rockets and mortars into Israel, prompting it to launch a wave of overnight airstrikes and dimming the prospects of a long-term truce.

articles.title: U.S. to Impose New Sanctions on Russia Over U.K. Nerve-Agent Attack
articles.summary: The U.S. announced new sanctions against Russia over a nerve agent attack targeting a former Russian spy and his daughter in the U.K.

articles.title: Powerful Aftershock Shakes Survivors of Indonesia Quake
articles.summary: A 6.2 magnitude aftershock sent thousands of residents of the Indonesian island of Lombok running into the streets and toppled buildings already weakened by Sunday’s magnitude 7.0 quake.
articles.byline: Ben Otto and I Made Sentana

articles.title: In Kandahar, U.S. Troops Remain, Even if Salsa Night Is Gone
articles.summary: The Boardwalk at Kandahar Air Field has always served as an apt metaphor for the state of the 17-year-old war in Afghanistan, and in important ways still does.

articles.title: Zimbabwe’s Crackdown Escalates With Detention of Opposition
articles.summary: A senior opposition politician has been taken into police custody in Zimbabwe after being deported from Zambia, in the latest escalation in a violent crackdown.

articles.title: Venezuela’s President Pushes Crackdown in Wake of Drone Attack
articles.summary: Two Venezuelan lawmakers face treason and terrorism charges as President Nicolas Maduro broadens a crackdown on political rivals he has accused of organizing an assassination plot shaking the troubled country.

articles.title: Talks Fail to Break Impasse on U.S. Pastor Held in Turkey
articles.summary: The U.S. failed to secure assurances from Turkey to immediately free an American pastor held for nearly two years on disputed terrorism charges, U.S. officials said, deepening a crisis between the two countries.

articles.title: U.S. Judge Dismisses Qatar from Broidy Hacking Lawsuit
articles.summary: A federal judge dismissed Qatar from a lawsuit filed by prominent Republican donor Elliott Broidy, who claims the tiny Persian Gulf nation was behind the hacking of his emails last year.

articles.title: Saudis Order Fund Managers to Dump Canadian Assets
articles.summary: Saudi Arabia is ordering its citizens to leave Canada, selling its financial assets there and freezing trade between the two countries as part of an extraordinary diplomatic spat.
articles.byline: Margherita Stancati in Beirut, Nicolas Parasie in Dubai and Paul Vieira in Ottawa

articles.title: Britain Tells Two Brexit Stories That Add Up to One Big Problem
articles.summary: To the governments of the other 27 European Union nations, the U.K. message is that failure to agree a Brexit deal would be a geopolitical calamity, but to the British public, the message has been one of reassurance.

articles.title: Congo President Won’t Run Again in Long-Delayed Election
articles.summary: Congolese President Joseph Kabila won’t run in long-delayed national elections, a government spokesman said, leaving a close party ally who is under European Union sanctions to vie for the leadership of the world’s largest cobalt producer.

articles.title: China Threatens Retaliatory Action After New U.S. Tariffs
articles.summary: China is shoring up its economy as it prepares for a long trade conflict with the U.S., with government data showing a surge in imports of resources including coal, oil and iron ore.

articles.title: The EU Spent a Bundle to Unify Europe. It’s Not Working
articles.summary: European leaders dedicated nearly one trillion dollars—equivalent to eight times the Marshall Plan—to fixing up impoverished regions. Yet some of the biggest recipients are hotbeds of the very discontent that’s driving the bloc apart.
articles.byline: Laurence Norman and Drew Hinshaw | Photographs by Piotr Malecki for The Wall Street Journal

articles.title: Indonesians Displaced by Quake Exceed 150,000
articles.summary: The number of people estimated to have been displaced by a powerful earthquake on Indonesia’s Lombok island rose to 156,000 on Wednesday, doubling dramatically overnight as rescuers pushed into new areas and struggled to bring supplies to survivors.
articles.byline: Ben Otto in Mangsit, Indonesia, and I Made Sentana in Jakarta

articles.title: IRS Agent Testifies Manafort Failed to Declare More Than $16 Million on Taxes
articles.summary: Paul Manafort didn’t declare more than $16 million in income to the U.S. Treasury over a five-year span, an IRS revenue agent testified Wednesday.
articles.byline: Del Quentin Wilber and Aruna Viswanatha

articles.title: Trump Submits Counteroffer to Mueller’s Terms for Interview
articles.summary: President Trump’s lawyers submitted a counteroffer to Special Counsel Robert Mueller’s proposal for the terms of a possible interview with the president, the latest turn in the protracted negotiations over a sit-down stretching back to January

articles.title: The Candidates Who Came in From the Cold
articles.summary: Being in the public eye isn’t always comfortable for several 2018 congressional candidates, most Democrats, who once worked in U.S. intelligence roles.

articles.title: This Week’s Elections Hold Warning Signs for Republicans
articles.summary: The elections held in five states underscored the Republican Party’s growing challenges with suburban voters, which could expand the battlefield in November’s midterms.
articles.byline: Reid J. Epstein and Andrew Duehren

articles.title: Rand Paul Delivers Letter From Trump to Putin During Moscow Trip
articles.summary: The senator tweeted that he was “honored” to deliver the letter, a move coming amid heightened scrutiny of the president’s relationship with the Russian leader.

articles.title: Most Candidates Backed by Ocasio-Cortez, Sanders Falter
articles.summary: The Democrats’ vocal, liberal wing sought to ride rising party enthusiasm to upset victories over more-centrist candidates or incumbents in Tuesday’s primaries across four states. Almost all of them came up short.

articles.title: What Comes Next for Ohio’s Tight Special Election?
articles.summary: Ohio’s House special election will not be certified by election officials for about two weeks as they comb through the last remaining votes.

articles.title: West Virginia Supreme Court Faces Impeachment Threat
articles.summary: West Virginia lawmakers voted to recommend the impeachment of all four sitting members of the state’s highest court on charges of abusing tax dollars.

articles.title: Senate Panel Seeks Testimony From Assange Over Russian Activity, WikiLeaks Says
articles.summary: WikiLeaks says in statement it is ‘considering the offer but testimony must conform to a high ethical standard.’

articles.title: Uncounted Ballots to Decide Critical Ohio, Kansas Races
articles.summary: Two high-stakes elections during the homestretch of primary season remained too close to call early Wednesday, foreshadowing the fierce battle to come around the nation in November’s midterms.
articles.byline: Reid J. Epstein and Andrew Duehren

articles.title: Trump Warms to Rosenstein After Nearly Firing Him
articles.summary: Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein has been a frequent target of President Trump’s ire as part of his disdain for the Russian election meddling probe. But in recent months, their relationship has stabilized.
articles.byline: Michael C. Bender and Sadie Gurman

articles.title: High-Stakes Races in Ohio, Kansas Are Too Close to Call
articles.summary: Two high-stakes elections in Ohio and Kansas during the homestretch of primary season were too close to call, foreshadowing the fierce battle to come around the nation in November’s midterms.
articles.byline: Reid J. Epstein and Janet Hook

articles.title: Missouri Overturns ‘Right-to-Work’ Law in Referendum
articles.summary: Missouri voters overturned a so-called right-to-work law in a referendum, giving organized labor a substantial victory.

articles.title: Manafort’s Attorney Presses Gates During Heated Exchange
articles.summary: An attorney for Paul Manafort pressed Richard Gates, Mr. Manafort’s longtime associate, on lies he admitted telling Mr. Manafort, prosecutors and his wife.
articles.byline: Aruna Viswanatha and Del Quentin Wilber

articles.title: U.S. to Impose Tariffs on Another $16 Billion in Chinese Imports
articles.summary: The Trump administration completed plans to impose new tariffs on $16 billion in Chinese imports, bringing the total value of products covered by the duties to $50 billion by the end of the month.

articles.title: In Ohio, a Key Election Could Be Bellwether for November
articles.summary: Ohio’s special election Tuesday is the highlight of a night that includes primaries in Washington state, Kansas, Michigan and Missouri. Here are the themes to watch.

articles.title: Worries Mount Over Ability to Weaponize Drones
articles.summary: Drone industry and law-enforcement officials are struggling to find common ground over expanding flights and protecting public safety, a debate thrust into the public spotlight by a reported assassination attempt on Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro.

articles.title: The Debate That Evenly Divides Economists: Is This a ‘Trade War?’
articles.summary: Economists remain divided—split exactly 50-50 in this month’s Wall Street Journal survey of private economists—on whether tariff actions to date warrant being labeled as a “trade war,” or whether they fall somewhere short of that standard.

articles.title: A Top Trump Donor’s Dealings With Michael Cohen Trigger Scrutiny
articles.summary: Federal prosecutors in New York have sought documents from Franklin L. Haney, a top donor to President Trump, about his dealings with Michael Cohen in connection with funding for a nuclear power project.
articles.byline: Rebecca Ballhaus, Michael Rothfeld and Joe Palazzolo

articles.title: MTA Official Accused of Using Taxpayer Funds to Buy $60,000 of iPhones
articles.summary: Manhattan district attorney’s office charges former MTA chief procurement officer with grand larceny.

articles.title: North Carolina Allows First Alligator Hunt in More Than 40 Years
articles.summary: A handful of hunters will soon be permitted to bag an animal rarely hunted in North Carolina: an American alligator.

articles.title: NYPD Arrests 22 in Queens Drug Bust
articles.summary: Twenty-two suspects connected to an alleged drug operation at the Queensbridge housing development have been arrested, the NYPD said.

articles.title: Industry-Backed Group Keeps Fighting Foam Ban
articles.summary: Restaurant owners largely shrug off the ban on foam containers, but an alliance with ties to a foam maker continues its battle
articles.byline: Gerald Porter Jr. and Corinne Ramey

articles.title: A Road Trip in Search of Burgers and Soft Serve
articles.summary: In gourmet-crazed New York, sometimes the best place to find classic, no-frills burgers and ice cream is upstate.

articles.title: New York Plans to Limit Uber and Lyft Drivers
articles.summary: New York moved to become the first city in the U.S. to cap ride-hailing services including Uber and Lyft, freezing new vehicle licenses for one year while it studies the fallout from the booming industry.

articles.title: GOP Rep. Collins Arrested on Charges of Insider Trading
articles.summary: Rep. Chris Collins, a New York Republican and early supporter of the Trump campaign, was arrested and charged by federal prosecutors with securities fraud and wire fraud.

articles.title: Father Is Suspect in Death of Baby Found in East River, NYPD Says
articles.summary: The Bronx man flew to Thailand the day after the 7-month-old child was found but was stopped by authorities when he arrived in Bangkok, New York City police said.

articles.title: Charges Against New York Rep. Collins Complicate Re-Election Bid
articles.summary: The insider-trading allegations that Republican Rep. Chris Collins is now facing complicate what was expected to be an easy path to re-election in his deep-red district near Buffalo.

articles.title: Rezoning of Manhattan’s Inwood Neighborhood Is Approved
articles.summary: The New York City Council voted Wednesday for a rezoning of the northern Manhattan neighborhood of Inwood, following  years of community engagement but also fierce opposition from residents who fear it will hasten gentrification.

articles.title: Cut Income Taxes or Kill Them? Connecticut GOP Candidates for Governor Disagree
articles.summary: The five Republicans in Connecticut’s gubernatorial primary agree on most things, except when it comes to state income tax.

articles.title: Gene-Editing Technique in Human Embryos Draws Skepticism
articles.summary: Scientists are challenging a high-profile study that found a popular gene-editing tool could be used to repair a disease-causing mutation in human embryos.

articles.title: Southern California Gas Agrees to Settlement for 2015 Methane Leak
articles.summary: The California utility has agreed to a $120 million civil settlement for a massive gas leak in 2015 that drove thousands of families from their Los Angeles homes.

articles.title: A Year After Charlottesville, the Alt-Right Frays
articles.summary: The violent Charlottesville, Va., rally last August energized the alt-right. But a year later, infighting, lawsuits and a social-media crackdown are hampering white nationalist and other right-wing groups, the groups’ leaders and people who track extremist groups say.

articles.title: Border Arrests Fell in July Amid Changes in Immigration Policy
articles.summary: The number of people arrested for illegally crossing the border declined for the second consecutive month in July, according to government arrest data.

articles.title: California Wildfire Raises Questions Over Urban Sprawl
articles.summary: The largest wildfire in California’s history is prompting questions about where people should live and build long-term in a state that has increasingly pushed new development into what are now fire-prone areas.

articles.title: SEC Probes Musk’s Tweets on Possible Tesla Buyout
articles.summary: The regulator is examining whether Tesla CEO Elon Musk’s statement on possibly taking the company private was truthful and inquired why the disclosure occurred on Twitter.

articles.title: Samsung Introduces Galaxy Note 9, a Smartphone Strikingly Like Its Predecessor
articles.summary: The Samsung Galaxy Note 9 looks much like last year’s Note 8, reflecting slowing smartphone innovation that has contributed to a historic dip in industry sales.

articles.title: Salesforce Adopts CEO Structure With Spotty Record
articles.summary: Salesforce’s elevation of Keith Block to co-chief executive creates a power-sharing structure that hasn’t always worked out for other companies.

articles.title: The Battery Pioneer Who, at Age 96, Keeps Going and Going
articles.summary: Four decades ago, John Goodenough helped invent the battery that is used to recharge cellphones, iPads and many other of today’s electronic goods. Now he wants to change the game again, working on a prototype of a liquid-free and cobalt-free battery.

articles.title: Slack Nears Close of Financing Round at $7 Billion Valuation
articles.summary: Slack Technologies Inc. is in the process of raising hundreds of millions of funding in a round that could include General Atlantic, Dragoneer and Wellington.

articles.title: Twitter Bucks Silicon Valley Trend, Opts Not to Ban Jones
articles.summary: Twitter Chief Executive Officer Jack Dorsey tweeted that his platform wouldn’t join other tech firms in banning parts or all of Alex Jones’s content. His reason: The Infowars host hadn’t violated Twitter policy.

articles.title: Snap’s Outlook Is Still a Stretch
articles.summary: The social network’s first forecast is offset by worries of a declining user base.

articles.title: Samsung to Spend $22 Billion on AI, Auto Tech and 5G
articles.summary: The conglomerate said it will invest the money over the next three years as it hunts for new growth drivers beyond phones and memory chips.

articles.title: Casper, a Web Pioneer, to Open 200 Stores
articles.summary: Online mattress seller Casper Sleep Inc. plans to open 200 of its own stores in the next three years, expanding across North America to stave off competition from dozens of internet copycats.

articles.title: Whole Foods Launches Online Grocery Pickup
articles.summary: Whole Foods is introducing pickup points for online grocery orders, the latest change Amazon.com is introducing to compete against rival food retailers.

articles.title: Upstart Poaches GE Executives as It Chases Predix Customers
articles.summary: As General Electric Co. looks to shed parts of its software unit, smaller competitors see an opportunity to challenge the conglomerate in a business it had hoped to dominate—using data to improve the performance of industrial machines.

articles.title: Italy’s UniCredit Has Stopped Advertising on Facebook
articles.summary: Italy’s largest bank, UniCredit, stopped advertising on Facebook in March, citing what it said was unethical behavior by the social-media giant related to a scandal involving data firm Cambridge Analytica.

articles.title: Venmo Social Feed Rankles Privacy Advocates
articles.summary: Venmo, an app owned by PayPal, lets users send money to one another for free along with a message. An uproar surrounding a web project studying the popular product shows why it rankles critics.

articles.title: Facebook Asks Big Banks to Share Data on Their Customers
articles.summary: Facebook has asked banks to share detailed financial information about customers, including account balances, as it seeks to boost user engagement. Facebook shares climbed sharply on the news.
articles.byline: Emily Glazer, Deepa Seetharaman and AnnaMaria Andriotis

articles.title: Magic Leap Headset Test: Off Your Phone, Into Your World
articles.summary: In one of the first demos, Magic Leap’s much-hyped One Creator Edition headset provides a look at the future of augmented reality and computer interaction.

articles.title: Saudi Billionaire Resumes Global Deal-Making
articles.summary: Saudi Prince al-Waleed bin Talal’s $500 million spending spree on technology firms this week marks the billionaire’s return to international deal-making, after he was ensnared in a corruption crackdown at home.

articles.title: Ousted Tech Founder? Uber’s Travis Kalanick Is in Good Company
articles.summary: Uber co-Founder Travis Kalanick joins an illustrious list of Silicon Valley leaders forced out of running the companies they built.

articles.title: Uber’s Really Bad Year
articles.summary: Uber CEO Travis Kalanick’s resignation follows a turbulent few months for both him and the company he founded. Here’s a quick glance at the events that preceded the 40-year-old’s departure.

articles.title: Not the Streaming Deal ‘Star Wars’ Fans Are Looking For
articles.summary: Walt Disney’s streaming service could have a troublesome absence when it launches late next year.

articles.title: Microsoft Surface Go Review: Small Computer, Big Compromise
articles.summary: Microsoft’s cheapest Surface yet tries to be both laptop and tablet. But in trying to be a perfect hand-held tablet and a powerhouse laptop, the Go risks getting neither right, writes David Pierce.

articles.title: Should Artificial Intelligence Copy the Human Brain?
articles.summary: The biggest breakthrough in AI, deep learning, has hit a wall, and a debate is raging about how to get to the next level.

articles.title: Tesla’s Big Question: Better or Worse Off as Private Company
articles.summary: Elon Musk is betting that taking Tesla private would free his company of scrutiny. But it could complicate efforts to build a mainstream electric car by removing the easy access to capital the Wall Street darling has enjoyed.

articles.title: Salesforce Promotes Block to Co-CEO
articles.summary: Salesforce.com promoted Chief Operating Officer Keith Block to co-chief executive, giving him shared leadership of the business-software company with its co-founder and chairman, Marc Benioff.

articles.title: Tesla’s Board Has Met Several Times to Discuss Going-Private Proposal
articles.summary: Tesla’s board has met several times over the past week to discuss Elon Musk’s proposal to take the company private in what would be the biggest buyout in history.

articles.title: Elon Musk Jolts Tesla Stock With Buyout Tweet
articles.summary: Tesla CEO Elon Musk’s surprise tweet suggesting he is considering taking the electric-car maker private sent its stock up 11% after a trading halt.

articles.title: Chinese Truck-Hailing App On Course for $10 Billion Valuation
articles.summary: Manbang Group, a Chinese truck-hailing platform that counts SoftBank and Alphabet as investors, is seeking to raise $1 billion in new funding.

articles.title: Experts Cast Doubt on Musk’s Envisioned Buyout of Tesla
articles.summary: A number of bankers and private-equity investors privately cast doubt on Elon Musk’s ability to pull off a buyout of Tesla after he raised the possibility in a series of tweets.

articles.title: Snapchat’s Users Slide in Latest Setback for Social Media
articles.summary: Snap reported that its number of daily active users fell by 2%, marking its first decline since being founded in 2011.

articles.title: Iranian Hackers Turn to Ransomware, Bitcoin as Economy Stalls
articles.summary: Over the past two years, researchers have tracked five new types of so-called ransomware they say were built by hackers in Iran.

articles.title: SoftBank to Invest in Alibaba’s New Delivery and Services Unit
articles.summary: The Japanese conglomerate is in talks to participate in fundraising of least $3 billion for a new Alibaba unit that would provide food delivery and local services.
articles.byline: Liza Lin in Shanghai and Mayumi Negishi in Tokyo

articles.title: Perrigo to Separate Its Prescription Pharmaceutical Business
articles.summary: Ireland-based Perrigo plans to shed its prescription pharmaceutical unit, which accounts for about one-fifth of total revenue, allowing the company to focus on expanding its consumer business.

articles.title: Consumer-Products Companies Stand Out in Management Top 250
articles.summary: Procter & Gamble, Nike and Colgate-Palmolive are among the leaders in all five of the ranking’s categories.

articles.title: Why Innovation Is a Team Sport
articles.summary: Companies that welcome ideas from all employees have better growth prospects than those with a less-inclusive approach to innovation, a new study finds.

articles.title: Viacom’s Revenue Falls on Slump in Ad Sales
articles.summary: Viacom’s revenue declined in the latest quarter as lower international sales from its filmed entertainment division, which includes Paramount Pictures, and advertising sales weighed on its top line.

articles.title: Heineken’s Strategy in a Stagnant Beer Market
articles.summary: CFO Laurence Debroux says the company’s best shot in the U.S. is to think locally.

articles.title: Booking Holdings Shares Fall on Lower Outlook
articles.summary: Shares of Booking Holdings fell in pre-market trading Thursday after the travel company delayed the release of its second-quarter results by half a day and provided a lower-than-expected outlook for the current quarter.

articles.title: Condé Nast Considers Layoffs as It Maps a Route to Growth
articles.summary: Condé Nast Chief Executive Bob Sauerberg outlined a plan to return to profitability in two years and revive growth, by diversifying its revenue away from advertising and shedding certain magazine titles.

articles.title: Adidas Earnings More Than Double Amid Nike Challenge
articles.summary: Adidas’s net income more than doubled after demand for World Cup merchandise boosted its sales growth, as the Germany company faces a fresh challenge on its home turf from Nike.

articles.title: A Fight at the Opera: Casino Battle on the Cards Over Iconic View
articles.summary: An Australian casino company is suing the government to protect a valuable asset: views of the iconic Sydney Opera House and Harbour Bridge. Crown Resorts is itself having a building constructed that’s expected to be some 75 stories tall.

articles.title: Rite Aid, Albertsons Call Off Tie-Up Amid Investor Opposition
articles.summary: The retailers said they mutually agreed to remain separate. Investors who opposed the $24 billion deal said it undervalued Rite Aid’s retail business and drug benefit service.

articles.title: Labor Unrest Strikes Mining Giants
articles.summary: Already grappling with challenges including U.S. tariffs and rising costs, global mining companies face another: worker walkouts. In Australia, roughly 1,500 employees are on strike at Alcoa mines and refineries.

articles.title: Stocks Little Changed Amid Positive Corporate Earnings
articles.summary: The S&P 500 edged lower Thursday, as the latest round of corporate-earnings reports offered some support to a stock market reckoning with yet another trade volley.

articles.title: A Shakespearean Drama at CBS
articles.summary: If you are going to plot a coup, make sure your secret texting software actually keeps its secrets.

articles.title: Oil Prices Steady After Sharp Fall
articles.summary: Oil prices steadied after falling sharply on expectations that crude would be drawn into the U.S.-China trade dispute, along with downward pressure from bearish U.S. stocks data.

articles.title: U.S. Government Bonds Jump on Soft Inflation Data
articles.summary: U.S. government bonds gained after the Labor Department said producer prices remained flat in July, falling short of economist forecasts for them to rise.

articles.title: Speculative Buyers Bid Up Copper
articles.summary: Copper prices climbed Thursday morning amid strong speculative appetite and stable Chinese inflation data.

articles.title: Treasury to Sell $122 Billion in Debt
articles.summary: The U.S. Treasury Department will auction $122 billion in securities next week, comprising 13-week, 26-week and 52-week bills.

articles.title: New Investor Guessing Game: What Is ‘New Fox’ Worth
articles.summary: Once Fox’s deal with Disney closes, the next question will be how to value what is left behind: Fox News and Fox Sports.

articles.title: The High Cost of Getting Your Wish at Rite Aid
articles.summary: Shareholders avoid unpopular deal, but drug store chain has a tough road ahead.

articles.title: Dollar Rises on Geopolitical Tension
articles.summary: The U.S. currency rose sharply against those including the Russian ruble and Turkish lira Thursday.

articles.title: Adidas Is Looking Fitter Than Nike
articles.summary: With its T-shirt wearing tech billionaires and health-conscious consumers, the U.S. is the spiritual home of the global sporting goods boom. But the fitter of the two sportswear giants feeding those consumers just now is European.

articles.title: Stocks to Watch: Tesla, 21st Century Fox, Sinclair, Viacom
articles.summary: Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively in Thursday’s session.

articles.title: The S&P Index That’s Hitting New Records
articles.summary: The S&P 500 Total Return Index is hitting new highs, while the more well-known S&P 500 stock benchmark trails close behind.

articles.title: Watch Out for China’s Slowing Car Sales
articles.summary: Chinese car sales clocked a second consecutive month of decline in July. Local brands look more exposed than Western peers.

articles.title: Chinese Lending Rates Drop Steeply to Three-Year Lows
articles.summary: Interest rates on short-term loans between Chinese banks have sunk to three-year lows, as Beijing attempts to stimulate the economy by ensuring lenders have plenty of cheap funding to support businesses and consumers.

articles.title: Redfin shares down nearly 7% after company casts doubt on real-estate market
This one lifestyle choice matters more than making money
E.L.F. Beauty is shifting its strategy … about six months too late, analysts say
A Mansion in Montecito, California, Built for a Baron Listed for $40 Million
Northern California Dominates List of Fastest-Growing Luxury Markets in U.S.
U.K. Tax Changes Put Off Potential Landlords
The Premier League Has a Manchester City Problem
articles.summary: With Manchester City fully rearmed to defend its title as the season starts Friday, English soccer’s competitive balance is in danger and the club’s dominance is a major problem for the most popular league on the planet.

articles.title: The Year of the Golf Free Agent Is Here
articles.summary: Some of golf’s most recent major champions have chosen competitive freedom over guaranteed money, opting to play whichever combination of clubs they prefer, rather than using only equipment from a single company that pays them.

articles.title: The LeBron James Interview About Bicycles
articles.summary: LeBron James is arguably the world’s greatest basketball player. He’s also a serious cyclist, and he’s giving every student at his new school a bicycle. In an interview with Jason Gay, the NBA superstar holds court about bikes.

articles.title: NFL’s New Safety Rule Has Spawned an Existential Crisis
articles.summary: A new helmet rule imposed by the NFL this off-season has been the focus of exasperation from players and coaches alike since training camp began.

articles.title: The Mets Are So Bad They Killed the Win
articles.summary: Thanks to his team’s putrid offense, Mets ace Jacob deGrom has a losing record, which could very well end up costing him the Cy Young Award.

articles.title: Women’s Soccer’s New Play: A $1 Million Locker Room
articles.summary: In the middle of its sixth season, the National Women’s Soccer League has lasted twice as long as either of its two predecessors. Salaries are inching up, fan support is growing and, most noteworthy, more owners are investing in facilities and operations.

articles.title: Eugenio Suarez Can Run and Chew Gum at the Same Time
articles.summary: The Reds’ all-star third baseman has a talent for blowing giant bubbles, even while in the field or running the bases

articles.title: Who’s Super Stoked About Spikeball? Beach Bros—and Mennonites
articles.summary: Turns out the best players of the oceanside game are in Lancaster County, Pa., where Amish and Mennonites share a passion with dudes in board shorts; ‘The Hand of God’ brings a win.

articles.title: NFL, Players Union Look to Tackle Anthem Policy...Again
articles.summary: With the first exhibition game taking place Thursday, the NFL and the NFL Players Association are attempting to come up with clear anthem rules and avoid repeating the mistakes of the spring’s ill-fated attempt.

articles.title: Urban Meyer and the God Complex in College Sports
articles.summary: With another university entangled in controversy, this time Ohio State and head football coach Urban Meyer, Jason Gay calls for the statues to come down and to humanize the leaders in charge.

articles.title: Get Ready for a Wild Finish as National League Heats Up
articles.summary: As the calendar turns to baseball’s home stretch, all three divisions in the National League are separated by half a game or less, in what could be a historic pennant race.

articles.title: Urban Meyer on Leave as Ohio State Investigates Allegations
articles.summary: One of college football’s most successful coaches was sidelined on Wednesday as the school probes when he became aware of recent domestic-violence allegations involving a former Buckeyes assistant coach.

articles.title: The NBA’s Billion-Dollar Bear Market
articles.summary: It became clear this summer that the league now has a curious economy: NBA salaries are reflections, more than ever before, of when players happened to be free agents.

articles.title: Why Major League Pitchers Are Avoiding the Strike Zone
articles.summary: Across the major leagues this season, pitchers are having unexpected success by throwing more pitches out of the strike zone—on purpose.

articles.title: The Switcheroo That Won Team Sky the Tour de France
articles.summary: Geraint Thomas was supposed to support four-time defending champion Chris Froome. But Thomas proved he was the stronger rider for Team Sky and kept the yellow jersey.

articles.title: The Uncomfortable Practice Habits of a Champion
articles.summary: Francesco Molinari won the British Open after adopting routines designed to simulate the pressure of competition.

articles.title: Why More Position Players Are Pitching
articles.summary: An occurrence once viewed as the ultimate novelty in baseball has suddenly become commonplace as teams seek to save their bullpens.

articles.title: The Lost Art of Switch Hitting
articles.summary: In 1992, switch hitters accounted for nearly 20% of the plate appearances across baseball. The number sits at 13% this season and will almost certainly decline.

articles.title: Cycling’s Best Performance Enhancer: The Peloton
articles.summary: According to a new study, riders in the belly of a peloton are exposed to 95% less drag than they would experience riding alone.

articles.title: Bryce Harper Is Limping Toward Free Agency
articles.summary: While he’s leading the National League in walks and homers, Bryce Harper is hitting just .216 entering Thursday—the ninth-worst rate in the majors among 159 batting average qualifiers.

articles.title: Geraint Thomas Takes Control of the Tour de France
articles.summary: Barring a crash, Geraint Thomas is now set to ride into Paris on Sunday wearing the yellow jersey.

articles.title: Team Sky’s Tour Problem: Two Cyclists, Only One Yellow Jersey
articles.summary: Chris Froome is aiming for his fifth Tour de France title. But this year, the man in front of him is his Team Sky teammate Geraint Thomas.

articles.title: Ryan Lochte Hit With 14-Month Doping Ban
articles.summary: Swimmer Ryan Lochte has accepted a 14-month sanction from the U.S. Anti-Doping Agency for getting an intravenous injection in May.

articles.title: NCAA Tweaks Amateur Rules for College Basketball Players
articles.summary: The NCAA has announced modest changes to amateurism rules in college basketball that will allow top prospects to have official relationships with agents and return to school if they go undrafted.

articles.title: Urban Meyer Tweets, and the Ohio State Football Crisis Takes a Turn
articles.summary: The widening scandal that may cost Buckeyes coach Urban Meyer his job shows how much the perception of wrongdoing in college sports has changed over the last decade.

articles.title: Jose Reyes’s Pitching Was Almost as Bad as His Hitting
articles.summary: Mets infielder Jose Reyes could become just the third position player since baseball’s Expansion Era began in 1961 to allow more runs as a pitcher than he drove in as a hitter.

articles.title: How to Save Baseball: Let Fans Pitch
articles.summary: Since some big league managers are fine with using position players to burn innings, the WSJ's Jason Gay believes that letting fans pitch in blowouts would help boost Major League attendance.

articles.title: SEC Probes Musk’s Tweets on Possible Tesla Buyout
articles.summary: The regulator is examining whether Tesla CEO Elon Musk’s statement on possibly taking the company private was truthful and inquired why the disclosure occurred on Twitter.

articles.title: On Planes, Dogs Are Winning
articles.summary: New airline rules haven’t stopped an increase in pets, including emotional-support animals, on airplanes, leading to more incidents and questions about whether the government should step in.

articles.title: Tribune Terminates $3.9 Billion Merger With Rival Sinclair
articles.summary: Tribune Media terminated its merger agreement with rival TV station-owner Sinclair Broadcast Group and sued the company, alleging it failed to make sufficient efforts to get their $3.9 billion deal approved.

articles.title: Elon Musk’s Flawed Plan for Tesla Shareholders
articles.summary: Elon Musk’s latest piece of showmanship—an offer to take electric-car maker Tesla private—amounts to a slap in the face for shareholders, writes James Mackintosh.

articles.title: New York Plans to Limit Uber and Lyft Drivers
articles.summary: New York moved to become the first city in the U.S. to cap ride-hailing services including Uber and Lyft, freezing new vehicle licenses for one year while it studies the fallout from the booming industry.

articles.title: Everyone* Pours Bacon Fat Down the Drain, Everyone Lies About It
articles.summary: *Except people who know better and are appalled at such a thing. Eventually a plumber will sort out the giant grease clog, evidence of America’s secret shame. ‘He still doesn’t know that it was me.’

articles.title: Saudis Order Fund Managers to Dump Canadian Assets
articles.summary: Saudi Arabia is ordering its citizens to leave Canada, selling its financial assets there and freezing trade between the two countries as part of an extraordinary diplomatic spat.
articles.byline: Margherita Stancati in Beirut, Nicolas Parasie in Dubai and Paul Vieira in Ottawa

articles.title: Photos Capture Devastation From Carr Fire in California
articles.summary: Survey some of the damage from the Carr fire, the fifth most-destructive fire in California history, in aerial photos taken by the city of Redding.
articles.byline: Dave Cole | Photographs by the City of Redding

articles.title: The Battery Pioneer Who, at Age 96, Keeps Going and Going
articles.summary: Four decades ago, John Goodenough helped invent the battery that is used to recharge cellphones, iPads and many other of today’s electronic goods. Now he wants to change the game again, working on a prototype of a liquid-free and cobalt-free battery.

articles.title: GOP Rep. Collins Arrested on Charges of Insider Trading
articles.summary: Rep. Chris Collins, a New York Republican and early supporter of the Trump campaign, was arrested and charged by federal prosecutors with securities fraud and wire fraud.

articles.title: Rite Aid, Albertsons Call Off Tie-Up Amid Investor Opposition
articles.summary: The retailers said they mutually agreed to remain separate. Investors who opposed the $24 billion deal said it undervalued Rite Aid’s retail business and drug benefit service.

articles.title: Talks Fail to Break Impasse on U.S. Pastor Held in Turkey
articles.summary: The U.S. failed to secure assurances from Turkey to immediately free an American pastor held for nearly two years on disputed terrorism charges, U.S. officials said, deepening a crisis between the two countries.

articles.title: The EU Spent a Bundle to Unify Europe. It’s Not Working
articles.summary: European leaders dedicated nearly one trillion dollars—equivalent to eight times the Marshall Plan—to fixing up impoverished regions. Yet some of the biggest recipients are hotbeds of the very discontent that’s driving the bloc apart.
articles.byline: Laurence Norman and Drew Hinshaw | Photographs by Piotr Malecki for The Wall Street Journal

articles.title: Facing a Critical Shortage, Airlines Scramble to Hire New Pilots
articles.summary: Airlines are boosting salaries and setting up training centers to combat what is projected to be one of the biggest-ever pilot shortfalls. In recent years, travel has picked up, but the bench of available pilots hasn’t expanded enough to keep pace.
articles.byline: Robert Wall in London and Andrew Tangel in Chicago

articles.title: How Long Can Trump Play Good Cop, Bad Cop With North Korea?
articles.summary: President Trump says denuclearizing North Korea is going well, but his top aids disagree. The WSJ's Gerald F. Seib explains how Trump's strategy might be to play the nice guy. Photo: Getty

articles.title: Oil Shocks Changed the Auto Industry; Tariffs Could Change It Again
articles.summary: To understand why auto tariffs are such a contentious issue today, it helps to go back to the 1970s—with U.S. carmakers dominating the country’s auto market, Japan’s export growth on the horizon, and impending conflict in the Middle East. Photo: AP

articles.title: Surface Go: Microsoft's One Device Doesn't Rule Them All
articles.summary: It's a little bit tablet and a little bit laptop, but should the $400 Surface Go really be your next computer? WSJ's David Pierce tries the new device on for size. Photo/Video: Emily Prapuolenis/The Wall Street Journal

articles.title: Test Driving Magic Leap’s Augmented-Reality Goggles
articles.summary: The most hyped AR tech is finally for sale. WSJ’s Joanna Stern went to Florida to wear Magic Leap’s One Creator Edition headset and chase virtual dinosaurs and basketball legends.

articles.title: California Suffers Largest Fires in State History
articles.summary: The Mendocino Complex fire in Northern California has just grown to become the largest wildfire in state history, devouring more than 290,000 acres. Photo: Getty Images

articles.title: Why the Texas Senate Race Is So Intriguing
articles.summary: Democratic Congressman Beto O'Rourke is challenging Sen. Ted Cruz's seat in Texas this November. WSJ's Gerald F. Seib explains why this general race might be fun to watch. Photos: Getty/AP

articles.title: What Ohio’s Special Election Says About the Midterms
articles.summary: Ohio's Aug. 7 special election to fill a vacant House seat offers a good window into the issues Democrats and Republicans will likely focus on this fall. WSJ's Gerald F. Seib explains. Photo: Getty

articles.title: What's the Real Goal Behind Trump’s Iran Sanctions?
articles.summary: The Trump administration said it would soon restore sanctions against Iran. The WSJ's Gerald F. Seib looks at a possible reason behind the policy change. Photo: Getty

articles.title: Indonesian Earthquake Witness: ‘It's Like Walking Into a Disaster Zone.’
articles.summary: Witnesses described scenes of the deadly magnitude 7.0 earthquake that rocked Indonesia's popular tourist islands, leaving scores dead and thousands displaced. Photo: Getty Images

articles.title: Will Mueller Finish His Investigation Before or After the Midterms?
articles.summary: Special counsel Robert Mueller is pushing forward in the Russia probe, but some fear the investigation will influence the midterms. WSJ's Gerald F. Seib explains why. Photo: Getty

articles.title: Test Driving Magic Leap's Augmented-Reality Goggles
articles.summary: The most hyped AR tech is finally for sale. WSJ’s Joanna Stern went to Florida to wear Magic Leap’s One Creator Edition headset and chase virtual dinosaurs and basketball legends.

articles.title: This 22-Acre Island is Montana's Largest Private Estate
articles.summary: Shelter Island is home to Montana's largest private estate, which was completed in 2011.

articles.title: How Long Can Trump Play Good Cop, Bad Cop With North Korea?
articles.summary: President Trump says denuclearizing North Korea is going well, but his top aids disagree. The WSJ's Gerald F. Seib explains how Trump's strategy might be to play the nice guy. Photo: Getty

articles.title: Oil Shocks Changed the Auto Industry; Tariffs Could Change It Again
articles.summary: To understand why auto tariffs are such a contentious issue today, it helps to go back to the 1970s—with U.S. carmakers dominating the country’s auto market, Japan’s export growth on the horizon, and impending conflict in the Middle East. Photo: AP

articles.title: Why the Texas Senate Race Is So Intriguing
articles.summary: Democratic Congressman Beto O'Rourke is challenging Sen. Ted Cruz's seat in Texas this November. WSJ's Gerald F. Seib explains why this general race might be fun to watch. Photos: Getty/AP

articles.title: California Suffers Largest Fires in State History
articles.summary: The Mendocino Complex fire in Northern California has just grown to become the largest wildfire in state history, devouring more than 290,000 acres. Photo: Getty Images

articles.title: Surface Go: Microsoft's One Device Doesn't Rule Them All
articles.summary: It's a little bit tablet and a little bit laptop, but should the $400 Surface Go really be your next computer? WSJ's David Pierce tries the new device on for size. Photo/Video: Emily Prapuolenis/The Wall Street Journal

articles.title: What's the Real Goal Behind Trump’s Iran Sanctions?
articles.summary: The Trump administration said it would soon restore sanctions against Iran. The WSJ's Gerald F. Seib looks at a possible reason behind the policy change. Photo: Getty

articles.title: A Competitive Eater Explains Unlimited Smartphone Plans
articles.summary: Confused by those unlimited data plans from AT&T, Verizon, T-Mobile and Sprint? Competitive eater Carmen Cincotti helps WSJ's Joanna Stern explain the ups and downs of an all-you-can-eat deal.

articles.title: Will Mueller Finish His Investigation Before or After the Midterms?
articles.summary: Special counsel Robert Mueller is pushing forward in the Russia probe, but some fear the investigation will influence the midterms. WSJ's Gerald F. Seib explains why. Photo: Getty

articles.title: MDC Partners Grapples With Client Cutbacks in Second Quarter
articles.summary: MDC Partners missed its earnings expectations in the second quarter, as the advertising-holding company continued to struggle with client cutbacks, slowdown in new business processes and other business challenges.

articles.title: Ad Giant Omnicom Agrees to Buy Small Consulting Firm
articles.summary: Omnicom Group has agreed to acquire Dallas-based consulting firm Credera, the latest instance of an ad-services business investing in consulting services.

articles.title: Facebook’s New Message to WhatsApp: Make Money
articles.summary: WhatsApp detailed plans to sell ads and charge big companies that want to reach their customers through its service, launching its first major revenue streams as growth at Facebook’s main app is starting to decelerate.

articles.title: ComScore to Debut First Ad Product Under New CEO
articles.summary: ComScore is preparing to launch a new product that measures ad views across platforms like TV and mobile, the first big move by new Chief Executive Bryan Wiener, who has been charged with turning around the beleaguered business.

articles.title: Facebook’s Next Challenge: Less Data to Target Ads
articles.summary: Facebook’s advertisers in Europe are on the front lines of its efforts to tighten privacy practices, and their frustrations help explain why the social-media giant’s troubles are far from over.

articles.title: WPP Veteran Read Has Emerged as Leading CEO Choice
articles.summary: WPP PLC executive Mark Read has emerged as the leading contender to take over as chief executive of the advertising giant, according to people familiar with the matter, following the departure of founder Martin Sorrell.

articles.title: Facebook’s Challenge: Draw More Ad Dollars Beyond Core Platform
articles.summary: With Facebook’s relentless growth no longer a given on its main platform, the social-media titan now faces a question that was previously an afterthought: How to squeeze more money from its other apps and services?

articles.title: Amazon’s Profit Soars to Record
articles.summary: Amazon’s profit topped $2 billion for the first time, powered by the company’s newer services businesses that are ushering it into an era of swelling profitability.

articles.title: AMC Partners With Sorenson to Sell Targeted TV Ads
articles.summary: AMC will be able to serve different ads to different households using Sorenson technology, and charge a premium

articles.title: Viewers Cut the Cable TV Cord Faster Than Expected
articles.summary: Research firm estimates the ranks of U.S. cord-cutters will grow this year by 8 million, or nearly 33%, to 33 million.

articles.title: IPG Delivers a Dose of Good News for an Ad Industry Facing Challenges
articles.summary: Interpublic Group of Cos. beat expectations for the second quarter and raised its forecast for the year.

articles.title: WPP in Talks to Sell Minority Stake in Chinese Unit
articles.summary: WPP has held talks to sell a minority stake in its operations in China, as the world’s largest advertising company reviews its business after founder Martin Sorrell’s exit.

articles.title: Shares in Ad Giants Fall as Publicis Sales Disappoint
articles.summary: Shares in some of the biggest ad companies tumbled after Publicis reported revenue below expectations, heightening investors’ concerns.

articles.title: Big Advertisers Embrace Blockchain to Root Out Digital Spending Waste
articles.summary: Nestle, Anheuser-Busch and Bayer are among the big consumer marketers using blockchain to avoid the so-called advertising tech tax, or wasted spending on digital ads.

articles.title: Private-Equity Firm Silver Lake Offers to Invest $500 Million in iHeartMedia
articles.summary: Private-equity firm Silver Lake has reached out to iHeartMedia and its largest creditor group with an offer to invest about $500 million in the radio station operator.

articles.title: Startup Thinks Blockchain Can Help Fix the Media’s Business Woes
articles.summary: The company is trying to sell a maximum of $34 million in “tokens,” digital currency that its owners can use in a new online marketplace for media ventures being created by the company.

articles.title: Omnicom Boosts Data Effort With New Marketing Platform
articles.summary: Ad giant Omnicom has created a one-stop-shop for its agencies and clients to create, plan and execute campaigns using reams of third-party data.

articles.title: Fox Losing Money on World Cup Without U.S. Team
articles.summary: 21st Century Fox is expected to lose money on covering the World Cup after early rounds of the no-U.S.-squad tournament drew nearly a third fewer viewers than in 2014.

articles.title: WPP Has a New Rival: Its Founder
articles.summary: The bitter breakup between advertising giant WPP and Martin Sorrell took another turn after Mr. Sorrell outbid his former company for Dutch digital production firm MediaMonks.

articles.title: Election Tech Providers Join Cybersecurity Group to Bolster Systems Ahead of Midterms
articles.summary: A group of elections technology vendors on Wednesday announced plans to partner with an IT-focused cybersecurity information sharing group to better protect voting infrastructure amid allegations of a widespread Russian effort to interfere in the 2016 U.S. election.

articles.title: DreamWorks Looks to Reanimate Business With Advanced Analytics
articles.summary: “From a pure data and computational aspect … you get nothing for free,” CTO Jeff Wike tells CIO Journal. "Every blade of grass, every eyelash, every drop of rain has to be built from scratch, and time and time again.”

articles.title: The Morning Download: DreamWorks Spins Tale With Analytics as the Hero
articles.summary: DreamWorks earlier this summer began working with its longtime technology service provider, cloud-based data services company NetApp Inc., on predictive analytics tools that would allow artists to render and prototype animated scenes rapidly without driving up compute costs by always accessing data from the cloud.

articles.title: General Dynamics Taps Insider to Lead Federal IT Push
articles.summary: Christopher Marzilli, a 20-year veteran at the defense giant, will oversee its growing federal information technology division

articles.title: MGM Resorts Bets on Tech Talent as AI Transforms Hospitality Industry
articles.summary: MGM Resorts International is hiring technologists who can help the global entertainment resort company develop consumer-facing software in areas such as artificial intelligence, as technology becomes ever more central to its future growth.

articles.title: Silicon Valley Bank Seeks to Up Its Tech Game
articles.summary: After years of helping startups secure cash to develop innovative digital tools, the Santa Clara-based lender hopes to boost its own tech capabilities with two new IT executives.

articles.title: Internet of Things Adoption to Rise Despite Security, Data Integration Challenges
articles.summary: While companies are expanding existing IoT projects and launching new ones, many expect it will take longer than previously thought to scale within their organizations, according to a survey of more than 600 IoT decision-makers polled by consulting firm Bain & Co.

articles.title: Tech Hiring Rebounds in July
articles.summary: After shedding IT jobs for four consecutive months, U.S. employers last month added 75,000 new IT workers and posted more ads for open tech positions, CompTIA reports.

articles.title: The Emergence of a Blockchain-Based Token Economy
articles.summary: The internet was designed to move information, but it’s lacked the necessary trust, security and privacy safeguards to move assets of value, CIO Journal Columnist Irving Wladawsky-Berger writes.  With blockchain, we’re now seeing the emergence of such an internet of value.

articles.title: Experian Enlists Machine Learning to Gauge App Performance
articles.summary: Just as manufacturing firms add sensors to monitor the performance of generators and compressors, Experian is using machine learning to create behavior models of applications. When data indicates behavior outside the normal range, application or infrastructure teams receive an alert. “I would equate this to predictive maintenance,” said CIO Barry Libenson.

articles.title: Microsoft Narrows Gap with Amazon in Cloud
articles.summary: Though Amazon maintains a commanding lead in cloud infrastructure, the software gian nearly doubled its share of the market, Gartner reports.

articles.title: In Rush Toward ‘Digital Transformation,’ Corporations Often Skirt IT
articles.summary: In the rush to deploy AI, automation and other tools for business-side divisions, many corporate IT units are neglecting their own digital upgrades, a Hackett Group report says.  That can spell trouble for the entire company.

articles.title: Lockheed Martin Deploys Augmented Reality for Spacecraft Manufacturing
articles.summary: Lockheed Martin’s space division is using augmented reality headsets and software to speed up the time it takes for engineers to learn about and conduct manufacturing processes on spacecraft

articles.title: Farm to Cradle: Nestlé Experiments with Tracking Gerber Baby Food on the Blockchain
articles.summary: Nestlé SA is putting some of its Gerber baby food products on a food-tracking blockchain to test whether the technology can trace the fruits and vegetables that go into its purées and squeezable pouches.

articles.title: Hertz Names New CIO as Tech Overhaul Continues
articles.summary: Opal Perry joins the rental-car agency as it continues a massive consolidation of its business systems and prepares to roll out updated versions of its core technology.

articles.title: Firms to Boost Spending on Smart Automation
articles.summary: In the rush to deploy artificial intelligence and robotic process automation, many businesses lack the in-house skills or business strategies to make those investments pay off, KPMG says.

articles.title: Pentagon Signs $885 Million Artificial Intelligence Contract with Booz Allen
articles.summary: The U.S. Department of Defense will for the first time be using large-scale AI systems that could automate mundane tasks and augment the work of military members. The contract also will go toward expanding AI-focused pilot programs, including using AI to find new approaches for treating traumatic brain injuries.

articles.title: Microsoft CTO: Edge Computing Can Make Industries ‘Massively More Efficient’
articles.summary: “Any of these agricultural or industrial applications, where you have very manual processes like inspections, or humans gathering data … (that’s where) the intelligent edge is going to make those industries massively more efficient,” says Microsoft CTO Kevin Scott.

articles.title: What Machine Learning Can and Cannot Do
articles.summary: As its domain of applications continues to expand, machine learning is raising serious concerns on its impact on automation and the future of work, CIO Journal Columnist Irving Wladawsky-Berger writes.

articles.title: Dow Chemical Digital Chief Helps Shape Massive Restructuring
articles.summary: Melanie Kalmar, Dow Chemical’s CDO and CIO, is working closely with other senior leaders to create a new structure designed to help the 121-year-old company better compete in the 21st century. "We are focused on a whole new realm of digitalization – one where we are harnessing the power of our long history of data collection to drive growth and new business opportunities," she said.

articles.title: Stop & Shop Owner Ahold to Streamline U.S. E-Commerce Platforms
articles.summary: Dutch grocer Ahold Delhaize is pruning back its e-commerce platforms in the U.S. and looking for partnerships in a bid to stabilize its position in the online groceries market, the company’s finance chief said.

articles.title: Travelers’ Longtime CFO Jay Benet to Exit
articles.summary: Travelers Cos. said veteran executive Jay Benet would step down as chief financial officer Sept. 1.

articles.title: Tough Choices Ahead for New GlaxoSmithKline CFO
articles.summary: GlaxoSmithKline PLC named a new finance chief, Iain Mackay, on Tuesday, appointing a former HSBC Holdings PLC executive to lead the U.K.  pharmaceuticals company through Brexit and a time of substantial change in drug development.

articles.title: Huntsman Mulls Repatriating Overseas Cash for Bolt-On Deals
articles.summary: Specialty chemicals maker Huntsman Corp. is considering repatriating some of its overseas cash following the introduction of a new provision in the U.S. tax law, the company’s finance chief said.

articles.title: Akzo Nobel Bets on Data to Hike Prices
articles.summary: Dutch paints maker Akzo Nobel NV is continuing to raise prices to offset higher raw material costs, the company’s finance chief said.

articles.title: Old Dominion Goes On Hiring Spree, Boosted by Robust Demand
articles.summary: Old Dominion Freight Line Inc., one of the largest U.S. truckers, has increased its headcount by 16% over the last quarter as the expanding economy has spurred demand.

articles.title: Companies Warn Currency Swings Will Weigh on Earnings
articles.summary: Multinational companies say billions of dollars in revenue and profit are at risk from recent currency fluctuations triggered by escalating tensions between the U.S. and its trading partners.

articles.title: Navient Readies For New Accounting Rules on Bad Loans
articles.summary: Navient Corp., one of the largest servicers of student loans, is preparing for a new accounting rule that requires lenders to project losses on bad loans quicker than current norms allow.

articles.title: U.S. Executives Keep Hoarding Cash as Trade Tensions Unfold
articles.summary: Executives at U.S. companies continued to accumulate cash in the second quarter, in a sign of wariness around escalating trade tensions, according to a new survey.

articles.title: Facebook’s ‘Chief Buzzkill’ Strikes Again
articles.summary: Finance chiefs are often the bearers of bad news during earnings calls, with share prices reaping the consequences. Facebook’s CFO Dave Wehner learned that lesson the hard way.

articles.title: Trump Organization Finance Chief Called to Testify Before Grand Jury
articles.summary: Allen Weisselberg, a longtime financial gatekeeper for President Trump, has been subpoenaed to testify in the criminal probe of Mr. Trump’s former personal lawyer, Michael Cohen.
articles.byline: Rebecca Davis O’Brien, Rebecca Ballhaus, Michael Rothfeld and Alexandra Berzon

articles.title: Godiva Names Former Burberry Executive as New CFO
articles.summary: Godiva Chocolatier has hired Virginie Costa as chief financial officer at the Brussels-based maker of chocolates and other confectioneries.

articles.title: Finance Chiefs Say Too Much Data Is Making It Harder to Manage Risks
articles.summary: Corporate finance chiefs say forming a cohesive and complete assessment of a company from proliferating data streams in an increasingly digital workplace has emerged as a top challenge.
